awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports organization and hosting of National Science Foundation (NSF) Spectrum Week 2024, a conference held in Arlington, Virginia on May 13-17, 2024. As in 2023, this week brings together three major programs funded through the NSF Spectrum Innovation Initiative program (SWIFT, NRDZ, and SpectrumX) to hold meetings and social events in a collaborative environment. New elements for 2024 include: co-location and coordination with IEEE DySPAN 2024 to foster publication and dissemination of peer-reviewed research results; the National Spectrum Managers Association (NSMA) industry trade group Annual Conference; and a Federal government outreach workshop for public engagement on the National Spectrum Research and Development plan.

The week of events is unique in the way it convenes a large cross-section of the spectrum research community as well as stakeholders in industry and government, and in so doing, integrate students into the forward-thinking conversations, networking, and career development opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hosted by the NSF and organized by SpectrumX, NSF Spectrum Week 2024 engaged the entire radio spectrum community, including academic, government, and industry radio spectrum researchers, policy experts, and those interested in radio spectrum education and workforce development. 

NSF Spectrum Week 2024 was an in-person gathering at the Hilton Arlington National Landing in Alexandria, Virginia, on May 13-17, 2024, and included four related events: SWIFT PI Meeting, NRDZCOM4, NSMA Annual Conference, SpectrumX Center Meeting, and WSRD Workshop. NSF Spectrum Week 2024 was also co-located with IEEE DySPAN, providing a preferred outlet for publication and dissemination of radio spectrum-related scholarly activities. Joint keynotes throughout the week, along with breakout sessions, poster sessions, and evening gatherings fostered collaboration across the spectrum ecosystem. 

SWIFT Principal Investigators Meeting - The NSF program Spectrum and Wireless Innovation Enabled by Future Technologies (SWIFT) (“NSF’s Spectrum Innovation Initiative | NSF”)

  • NSF’s fundamental research program in spectrum science

  • Program and project updates

  • Poster sessions to interact with each research team

  • Community work activity: How should SWIFT evolve, or what different program should replace it, to best meet the needs of the research community and the nation?

NRDZCOM4 - A Community Open Meeting of the NSF National Radio Dynamic Zone (NRDZ) (“Spectrum Innovation Initiative: National Radio Dynamic Zones (SII-NRDZ)”) program

  • NSF’s program to advance the use of dynamic spectrum sharing

  • Interactive discussion sessions:

  • SII-NRDZ field trials

  • Possible changes to regulations and processes

  • Data and protocol standards

SpectrumX Spring Center Meeting - SpectrumX (an NSF Spectrum Innovation Center) (“SpectrumX: Home”) is the world’s largest academic hub where all radio spectrum stakeholders are invited to innovate, collaborate and contribute to research, policy engagement and workforce development projects

  • Keynotes, panel discussions, and research talks featuring SpectrumX-affiliated faculty were held throughout the week.

  • Breakout sessions served as a Center overview and orientation for new and future corporate, government, and academic collaborators.

  • Friday session co-sponsored by WSRD and provided an outlet for academic input into the National R&D Plan under development by WSRD.

National Spectrum Management Association (NSMA) 2024 Annual Conference - For 20+ years, NSMA has hosted an annual conference to bring together a diverse group of participants to discuss the latest spectrum-related trends and developments. The conference’s topic areas are as diverse as the participants, and with increasing spectrum congestion, reallocations, sharing, and repurposing, it’s more important than ever to understand the radio spectrum environment from all angles. Prior NSMA conferences have been an excellent opportunity to meet and network with representatives from all sectors of the wireless industry. Co-location with NSF Spectrum Week 2024 built on this tradition.

WSRD Workshop - The R&D Plan will act as an organizing national document, providing guidance for government investments in spectrum-related research and offering valuable insights. The Plan will identify key innovation areas for spectrum research and development and will include a process to refine and enhance these areas on an ongoing basis. This workshop will provide an opportunity for the RFI respondents and others from academia, industry, and the public to engage in open dialog with the spectrum community and WSRD IWG authors on the potential content of the National Spectrum R&D Plan.
